title: J&J Could Increase $2 Billion Talc Settlement Offer, Lawyer Says; A lawyer for a bankrupt J&J subsidiary said the $2 billion offer is the starting point for negotiations and could increase if the chapter 11 case proceeds
text:
"We hope to have a mediation, to come to a consensus and a plan, to get the appropriate amount put in to resolve these cases," Mr. Kim testified

during the third day of trial in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Trenton, N.J.

Judge Michael Kaplan is considering injury claimants' request to dismiss the J&J subsidiary from chapter 11 on the grounds that the bankruptcy was filed in bad faith to gain an unfair litigation advantage. J&J and its subsidiary have denied the allegation and said bankruptcy will provide plaintiffs a fairer forum for quickly resolving about 38,000 talc-injury lawsuits as well as future claims.

Personal-injury lawyers have alleged the talc in Johnson's Baby Powder can cause ovarian cancer and contains asbestos, which J&J denies. It stopped selling the product in the U.S. and Canada in 2020 as the tort litigation grew.

Mr. Kim was questioned about J&J's response to the litigation over two days on the witness stand. On Tuesday, Mr. Kim testified that J&J was close last year to settling most of its talc liability for between $4 billion and $5 billion.

The deal, which involved the bankruptcy case of J&J's former talc supplier, fell apart in May or June, Mr. Kim said. J&J considered a corporate reshuffling that led to LTL's chapter 11 filing after the Supreme Court in June declined to review a $2.1 billion judgment in Missouri for 20 women who alleged the baby powder caused ovarian cancer. J&J has denied liability and said its talc products are safe.

Lawyers on Wednesday also played excerpts from an S&P Global Inc. analyst's videotaped deposition in which he said the LTL chapter 11 could help J&J's credit rating by quantifying the talc liability.

The trial is expected to conclude this week. Judge Kaplan has said he intends to rule by the end of the month on whether to dismiss LTL's case.
